content.text: The student ensures that the metre rule is horizontal
Briefly describe how to check that the metre rule is horizontal. You may draw a diagram or draw on Fig. 1.1 if it helps to explain your answer
The student moves the stands so that the vertical threads are at the marks on the metre rule shown in Fig. 1.2
Calculate the distance \(d\) between the threads
He twists the metre rule a small amount, as shown in Fig. 1.3, and then lets it go so that it oscillates in a rotating motion
He measures the time \(t\) for 5 complete oscillations of the metre rule
Suggest why it is useful to take a trial reading for this experiment
The student carries out the same procedure for \(d\) values of \(20.0 \text{cm}, 30.0 \text{cm}, 40.0 \text{cm}, 50.0 \text{cm}\) and \(60.0 \text{cm}\). His readings are shown in Table 1.1
For distance \(d = 20.0 \text{cm}\), calculate and record in Table 1.1, the value of \(\frac{1}{T}\) where \(T\) is the time for 1 oscillation of the metre rule
Use the value of time \(t\) from Table 1.1 and the equation \(\frac{1}{T} = \frac{5}{t}\)
Plot a graph of distance \(d / \text{cm}\) (y-axis) against \(\frac{1}{T} /\frac{1}{s}\) (x-axis)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
Explain why it is more accurate to measure the time for 5 oscillations rather than for 1 oscillation
Describe how the experiment could be improved to make the readings more reliable
A student investigates the motion of an oscillating metre rule
He uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 1.1
Record the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.1
Describe **one** precaution that you would take to ensure that temperature readings in the experiment are as accurate as possible
A volume of \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water is poured into each cup and the initial temperature \(\theta\) is recorded in Table 2.1
The temperature of the water in each cup is recorded every \(30 \text{s}\). The values are shown in Table 2.1
Complete the headings in Table 2.1
Write a conclusion stating which cup, A or B, is the more effective in reducing the cooling rate of the hot water in this experiment
Justify your answer by reference to the results
Calculate \(x_{\mathrm{A}}\), the average cooling rate for cup A over the whole experiment. Use the readings for cup A from Table 2.1 and the equation
where \(T = 180 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures at time \(t = 0\) and at time \(t = 180 \text{s}\). Include the unit for the cooling rate
Suggest an additional experiment to show how the lid affects the cooling rate of cup A
Explain how to use the additional results to show the effect
additional experiment
explanation
A student wishes to compare the effect of the materials of the cups on cooling rates. Suggest two variables that she should control to make this test fair
Students investigate the cooling of hot water in two different cups
They use the apparatus shown in Fig. 2.1
Cup A is made from thin plastic. The top of cup A has an inside diameter of \(7\mathrm{cm}\). Cup B is made from expanded polystyrene. The top of cup B has an inside diameter of \(8\mathrm{cm}\)
The student moves the crocodile clip on the resistance wire so that the value of the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{L}}\) across the lamp is \(2.0 \text{V}\)
She measures the current \(I\) for the lamp and resistor in series
She then connects the voltmeter to measure the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{R}}\) across the resistor
Fig. 3.2
Fig. 3.3
Read, and record in Table 3.1, the values of \(I\) and \(V_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the meters in Fig. 3.2 and Fig. 3.3
The student repeats the steps in **(a)** for values of \(V_{\mathrm{L}} = 1.0 \text{V}\) and \(V_{\mathrm{L}} = 0.5 \text{V}\)
Her readings are shown in Table 3.1
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the resistance of the lamp \(R_{\mathrm{L}}\) for each value of \(V_{\mathrm{L}}\)
Use the values of \(V_{\mathrm{L}}\) and \(I\) from Table 3.1 and the equation \(R_{\mathrm{L}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{L}}}{I}\)
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the resistance of the resistor \(R_{\mathrm{R}}\) for each value of \(V_{\mathrm{L}}\)
Use the values of \(V_{\mathrm{R}}\) and \(I\) from Table 3.1 and the equation \(R_{\mathrm{R}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{R}}}{I}\)
Describe the pattern of any change in the value of \(R_{\mathrm{L}}\) as \(V_{\mathrm{L}}\) decreases
A student suggests that \(R_{\mathrm{R}}\) should be constant
State whether your results support this suggestion
Justify your statement by reference to values from Table 3.1
statement
justification
A student wishes to determine the resistance of the lamp \(R_{\mathrm{L}}\) when the potential difference across the lamp \(V_{\mathrm{L}} = 0.0 \text{V}\)
Describe how the experiment can be extended to do this with the help of a suitable graph
It is possible to use a variable resistor instead of a resistance wire to change the potential difference across the lamp
Complete the circuit in Fig. 3.4 to show:
a variable resistor used for this purpose
the voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across the resistor
Fig. 3.4
A student investigates a resistor and a lamp connected in series
She uses the circuit shown in Fig. 3.1
A student investigates the motion of a ball rolling down a slope
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how **one** factor affects the average speed of the ball
Average speed can be calculated using the equation:
The apparatus available includes:
balls of various sizes and materials
a board which can act as a slope
blocks to support one end of the board
In your plan, you should:
state a factor which can be measured
list any additional apparatus needed
explain briefly how to carry out the experiment including exactly which measurements are to be taken
state the key variables to be kept constant
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan
